0.text: A constant sense of anxiety can seriously affect quality of life, getting in the way of work, social activity and overall well-being. People may start avoiding certain situations or places that trigger or intensify their anxiety.
0.fact: According to the World Health Organization, anxiety disorders are among the most common mental health conditions. They affect millions of people worldwide, and research suggests that roughly 1 out of 13 people globally experiences some form of anxiety disorder over the course of their life.

1.text: A sense of fear without an obvious reason can be a symptom of generalized anxiety disorder or other forms of anxiety, such as panic disorder.

2.text: How easily a person gets upset or panics can be linked to increased sensitivity to stress. This state is often associated with a low threshold of arousal in the nervous system, which makes a person more vulnerable to external and internal stimuli.
2.fact: Studies show that about 2–3% of the adult population worldwide experience panic disorder each year. Women are about twice as likely as men to develop this condition.

3.text: This feeling can be related to anxiety disorders, depression or stress. Difficulties concentrating and feeling in control often arise when the nervous system is overloaded, which leads to impaired cognitive functioning and emotional regulation.
3.fact: Charlie Hunnam, a well-known actor, has spoken publicly about his struggles with anxiety and how it sometimes makes it harder to focus on work and personal life. He emphasizes the importance of seeking professional help and using relaxation techniques.

4.text: A sense of well-being and confidence that everything will be all right is a sign of healthy confidence and optimism. This state supports better mental health and can lower levels of stress and anxiety.
4.fact: Research shows that optimism can even influence physical health. Optimistic people often have a lower risk of chronic diseases and tend to live longer than pessimists.

5.text: Trembling of the hands and feet can have many causes, including stress, fatigue, overexertion or caffeine. It can also be a symptom of medical conditions such as an anxiety disorder, hyperthyroidism or even early stages of neurological conditions like Parkinson’s disease.
5.fact: Anxiety disorders are among the most common mental health conditions, affecting millions of people worldwide. Around 31% of adults experience an anxiety disorder at some point in their lives.

6.text: Headaches and pain in the neck and back can be caused by many factors, including muscle tension, stress, poor posture, prolonged sitting or an uncomfortable position when working at a computer. These pains can also be symptoms of anxiety, which increases muscle tension and heightens the perception of pain.

7.text: According to statistics, about 10% of people worldwide suffer from chronic fatigue, which significantly affects their ability to perform everyday tasks.

8.text: Calmness and a lack of fuss are often associated with reduced stress, anxiety and depressive states. This condition supports better emotional regulation and can improve decision-making, as it allows a person to assess situations more objectively and calmly.
8.fact: Staying generally calm and unhurried can lower levels of cortisol, the stress hormone, which has a positive effect on the cardiovascular system, blood pressure and overall health.

9.text: Frequent episodes of a racing heartbeat can cause worry or fear, especially if they are perceived as unusual or dangerous. This may limit physical activity and social interactions out of fear of triggering another episode.

10.text: Dizziness can be a direct symptom of an anxiety disorder. During heightened anxiety the autonomic nervous system is activated, which leads to changes in blood circulation and, as a result, to feelings of light-headedness or dizziness.
10.fact: Dizzy spells linked to anxiety can make it difficult to carry out everyday tasks, take part in social events or work. This can create a vicious cycle where anxiety about symptoms intensifies the anxiety itself, maintaining or worsening the condition.

11.text: Fainting or feeling as if you are about to lose consciousness can be associated with vasovagal syncope, a condition in which an excessive activation of the parasympathetic nervous system in response to stress causes a sudden drop in blood pressure and heart rate. This is often seen in people with anxiety disorders.
11.fact: During acute anxiety or panic attacks, hyperventilation (rapid breathing) often occurs. This can lower the level of carbon dioxide in the blood and, as a result, lead to dizziness or loss of consciousness.

12.text: Free and deep breathing plays a key role in regulating the nervous system, helping to reduce stress and anxiety. It activates the parasympathetic nervous system, which promotes relaxation and decreases heart rate.
12.fact: Studies show that breathing exercises can reduce the production of stress hormones in the body and improve overall mental health. Regular practice can help achieve a deeper level of relaxation and lower everyday tension.

13.text: Numbness and tingling in the extremities can be related to anxiety, especially when they occur during panic attacks or periods of intense stress. These symptoms are often caused by hyperventilation, which leads to changes in blood flow and carbon dioxide levels in the blood, resulting in a temporary sensation of numbness or tingling.
13.fact: Although these symptoms are usually temporary, they can be worrying or frightening, especially when the cause is unknown. This can intensify anxiety, creating a vicious circle.

14.text: Stomach pain and digestive problems are common in people with anxiety disorders. Anxiety can increase the activity of the sympathetic nervous system, which changes digestive processes, speeding them up or slowing them down.
14.fact: Stress and anxiety can lead to stomach cramps, increased stomach acid secretion or even irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). These symptoms are psychosomatic — physical manifestations of psychological distress.

15.text: Frequent urges to urinate can be one of the physical symptoms of anxiety. Activation of the sympathetic nervous system in response to stress can increase activity of the bladder and urinary tract, which leads to more frequent urination.
15.fact: Research shows that frequent urges to urinate are found in a significant proportion of people with anxiety disorders. It is important to discuss these symptoms with a doctor to rule out other possible medical causes and to receive appropriate treatment for anxiety.

16.text: Chronic stress can negatively affect the skin’s barrier function and contribute to moisture loss, making the skin drier and less resistant to external irritants. This phenomenon is studied in psychodermatology, which explores how mental states influence the skin.

17.text: Facial flushing can be caused by anxiety and stress, which trigger the release of adrenaline. This hormone dilates blood vessels and increases blood flow to the facial skin, leading to redness.
17.fact: In moments of anxiety or stress, the facial blood vessels can expand, causing redness known as flushing. This is a natural bodily response to emotional tension and may be accompanied by a feeling of heat or burning.

18.text: A full night’s rest helps regulate emotions, improves cognitive functions and supports overall emotional well-being. People who regularly get quality sleep usually cope better with daily stress and are less prone to anxiety disorders.
18.fact: Sound sleep improves immune function and reduces the risk of chronic illnesses. Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, has also emphasized that proper sleep is key to maintaining his productivity and well-being.

19.text: Frequent nightmares can seriously disrupt sleep structure, leading to sleep deprivation, which in turn increases daytime fatigue and reduces overall quality of life. This can also contribute to the development of depression and other psychological disorders.

normal.text: Your result indicates a normal level of anxiety. At times you may experience mild worry or nervousness, but this is a natural part of life. This state does not require professional help; however, self-care and basic psychological hygiene are still important.
normal.title: Normal state

light.text: Your result suggests a mild level of anxiety. This may be related to stressful or unpleasant events such as relationship difficulties, financial concerns or life changes. Your mood may be lowered, but these states usually pass. Support from loved ones, rest and mindfulness practices can help you feel better.
light.title: Mild anxiety

severe.text: Your result points to an elevated level of anxiety that may significantly affect your mood, energy and ability to concentrate. It may be hard to stay optimistic, maintain productivity or feel emotionally stable. Support from a psychologist and regular self-help practices can assist you in managing anxiety and improving your state.
severe.title: Marked anxiety

extreme.text: Your result indicates severe anxiety, which may be accompanied by intense emotional discomfort and difficulties in daily life. If you feel down, experience distressing thoughts or find it hard to cope on your own, please reach out for professional support. You are not alone — help exists and can become an important step toward feeling better.
extreme.title: Severe anxiety

text: This self-rating anxiety test, developed at Duke University under the guidance of William Zang, helps assess the level of anxiety symptoms, including worry, panic reactions and tension. The ZARS (Zung Anxiety Rating Scale) allows you to better understand how much anxiety affects your daily life and emotional state.
